name: Myanmar
currentCrisisSummary:
Myanmar is engulfed in a nationwide civil war, pitting a broad revolutionary movement against the military junta that seized power in a 2021 coup. This is not merely a pro-democracy uprising but a struggle to dismantle a system of military rule that has dominated the country for over 60 years.

The conflict has united Bamar pro-democracy fighters in newly formed People's Defence Forces (PDFs) with long-established Ethnic Armed Organisations (EAOs) in an unprecedented, if complex, alliance. The military junta (the Tatmadaw) has responded with extreme brutality, employing air strikes, artillery bombardments, and scorched-earth tactics against civilian populations. This violence, once primarily confined to the ethnic peripheriesâ€”as demonstrated by the 2017 genocidal campaign against the Rohingyaâ€”is now being inflicted across the Bamar heartland, creating one of the world's largest internal displacement crises and a rapidly escalating humanitarian catastrophe.

colonialRoot.legacy:
British colonial policy created the fissures that define Myanmar's modern conflicts. Through a 'divide and rule' strategy, Britain administered the central Bamar lowlands separately from the 'Frontier Areas' inhabited by ethnic minorities. The British institutionalised ethnic identities and used minority groups like the Karen and Kachin in their colonial army, deepening divisions.

This administrative segregation ensured that at independence, Burma was not a unified nation but a fractured state, with a powerful Bamar-dominated centre and deeply distrustful ethnic peripheries. This structure of internal inequality and division was inherited and ruthlessly exploited by the post-colonial military.

historicalContext.theMilitaryAsAStateWithinAState: For over 60 years, the Tatmadaw has operated as a state within a state, functioning as a privileged political and economic class. Through two massive military-owned conglomerates, Myanmar Economic Holdings Ltd (MEHL) and Myanmar Economic Corporation (MEC), it controls vast swathes of the economy, from banking and breweries to jade mining. The 2021 coup was not just a political power grab but a violent move to protect this entrenched economic empire from the threat of democratic, civilian oversight.
historicalContext.khakiCapitalismAndTheFailedTransition: The decade of quasi-civilian rule (c. 2011-2021) was not a true democratic transition but a period of military-managed neoliberal reform. The economy was opened to foreign investment, but this capital often flowed into joint ventures with military conglomerates and their cronies, modernising their economic empire under a civilian facade. This 'khaki capitalism' enriched the elite and entrenched the military's power, while the much-lauded peace process was used to divide ethnic groups. The NLD government, led by Aung San Suu Kyi, was constrained by the military's constitutional power and failed to challenge the core structures of its repressive, Bamar-centric state, culminating in her defence of the military's genocide against the Rohingya.
historicalContext.postCoupRevolutionAndEthnicSolidarity: The 2021 coup ignited a nationwide revolution. Unlike previous uprisings, it has forged a powerful, if fragile, solidarity between the Bamar majority and many of the country's long-oppressed ethnic minorities. The opposition's National Unity Government (NUG) and its armed wings (PDFs) are fighting alongside veteran Ethnic Armed Organisations. The shared experience of the Tatmadaw's brutality has forced many Bamar democrats to confront the military's long history of atrocities against ethnic peoples like the Rohingya, creating the potential for a new, federalist vision for the country.
historicalContext.geopoliticalEnablersAndCorporateComplici: The junta's war effort is sustained by external support. Russia and China are its primary arms suppliers and provide diplomatic cover at the UN Security Council, blocking meaningful action like a global arms embargo. Regionally, ASEAN's response has been weak and ineffective. Furthermore, some multinational corporations, particularly in the oil and gas sector (like TotalEnergies and Chevron until their recent withdrawals), have been criticised for generating revenues that have flowed directly to the junta, effectively financing its campaign of terror against the population.

humanitarianImpact.displaced: Over 3 million people have been internally displaced since the 2021 coup, fleeing air strikes and military attacks.
humanitarianImpact.refugees: Hundreds of thousands have fled to neighbouring Thailand and India since the coup, in addition to the nearly 1 million Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh.
humanitarianImpact.casualties: At least 6,300 civilians have been killed by the junta since 2021, though the actual number is likely far higher. Total conflict deaths are in the tens of thousands.
humanitarianImpact.affected: An estimated 18.6 million peopleâ€”one-third of the populationâ€”require humanitarian assistance.
humanitarianImpact.foodInsecurity: Around 12.9 million people are facing acute food insecurity as the conflict has shattered supply chains and destroyed agricultural livelihoods.
humanitarianImpact.healthSystemCollapsed: The health system has collapsed after being systematically targeted by the junta, with hundreds of attacks on hospitals and medical staff.
humanitarianImpact.livelihoodsAndEconomicLoss: The economy has contracted severely since the coup, plunging millions into poverty.

timeline.event: **Independence**: Burma gains independence from Britain, immediately facing multiple ethnic insurgencies rooted in the unresolved questions of the colonial era.
**First Military Coup**: General Ne Win seizes power, ending a brief democratic period and beginning decades of isolationist, authoritarian military rule.
**8888 Uprising**: A nationwide popular uprising for democracy is brutally crushed by the military, killing thousands and cementing the Tatmadaw's role as the violent oppressor of its own people.

**The 'Opening'**: A period of quasi-civilian rule and neoliberal economic reform begins. While lauded internationally, the military retains ultimate power and modernises its business empire through partnerships with foreign capital.

**Rohingya Genocide**: The Tatmadaw unleashes a campaign of genocidal violence against the Rohingya minority, forcing over 750,000 to flee to Bangladesh. The act showcases the military's capacity for extreme brutality.
**Coup & Revolution**: The military annuls the 2020 election results and stages a coup. A massive civil disobedience movement quickly evolves into a nationwide armed revolution.

**Operation 1027 & Shifting Tides**: A coordinated offensive by an alliance of ethnic armies in late 2023 inflicts stunning defeats on the junta, leading to the loss of major towns and border crossings and shifting the war's momentum in favour of the resistance.

donate.description: A grassroots network supporting civil disobedience strikers, local aid groups, and community resilience projects inside Myanmar.
A multi-ethnic humanitarian service movement that provides emergency medical care, shelter, food, and documentation of atrocities in the conflict zones.

advocacy: Demand a comprehensive global arms embargo to stop the flow of weapons and aviation fuel to the junta.
Call for coordinated international sanctions on the junta's leaders and their economic networks, particularly the military-owned conglomerates.
Support the pro-democracy National Unity Government (NUG) and other actors in the resistance movement.
Advocate for robust cross-border humanitarian aid that bypasses the junta to reach those in liberated areas and internally displaced camps.
Support international accountability efforts, including the ICJ genocide case and investigations into the junta's widespread war crimes.

reading.title: The River of Lost Footsteps: A Personal History of Burma
reading.description: Thant Myint-U's sweeping history of Myanmar, tracing the deep historical forces that shape the present crisis.

reading.title: Burma's Spring: Aung San Suu Kyi and the New Struggle for the Soul of a Nation
reading.description: Jason Szep's reporting offers a critical look at the complex political landscape leading up to the coup.

reading.title: From the Land of Green Ghosts: A Burmese Odyssey
reading.description: Pascal Khoo Thwe's memoir offering a vital perspective on ethnic minority life and the long struggle against the Bamar-dominated state.
